yes erUSUL ?: ok...here's my issue. Say I have Firefox open and 8,000 pages open, and firefox is usijng 500Mb of RAM, 300MB is VIRT
I have another application open using 500Mb of memory, and say i Only have 512Mb of memory
so part of program B is in swap. I close firefox, and I'd like program B to be moved out of swap
how did you measure the memory use?
swap space used "234916k"     ....   total Mem free: "201960k"
it just bugs me that stuff stays in swap when i have open memory for it

stuff is paged back into physical memory when it's used. free physical memory will be used for block caches, so it makes linux faster. if this bugs you you can change the swappiness factor in the kernel
it isn't using the pages that are in swap
as long as it doesn't use them, the pages won't swap. linux doesn't swap whole processes at a time, but pages at a time (4 or 8 KiB)
have fun :-) and remember that VIRT != memory usage
i have that imprinted in my braind now forever =)
good, it will get you far in life :-)
the closest metric you should use is RSS(/RES) which tells how much of virtual memory is present in physical memory at the moment
so RSS should increase when a process gets some of its pages back from swap
and RSS will decrease normally when pages are swapped to disk
